question: Question_05_(b)
statement:
Evaluate the double integral
$\displaystyle \iint_{D}y\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}}\,dA$ over the region
$\displaystyle D = \{(x,y)\,|\,x^{2} + y^{2} \le 2 \,\,\mbox{and}\,\, 0 \le y \le x\}$.
sols:
We use the change of variables from cartesian coordinates to polar
coordinates\[\displaystyle \begin{pmatrix}x\\y\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}r\cos(\phi)\\r\sin(\phi)\end{pmatrix}\]

The region of integration in polar coordinates is
$\displaystyle D=\{(r,\phi)|\ r\in[0,2],\ \phi\in[0,\frac{\pi}{4}]\}$.
The function $\displaystyle y\sqrt{x^2+y^2}$ becomes
$\displaystyle r^2\sin(\phi)$. The volume factor for polar coordinates
is $\displaystyle r$. Hence,

\begin{align*}
\iint_Dy\sqrt{x^2+y^2}\;\text{d}A &= \int_0^2\int_0^{\frac{\pi}{4}}r^2\sin(\phi)r\;\text{d}\phi\text{d}r\\
=& \int_0^2r^3[-\cos(\phi)]_0^{\frac\pi4}\;\text{d}r\\
=& \left[\frac14r^4\right]_0^2(-\cos(\frac\pi4) + \cos(0))\\
=& 4\left(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) = 4-2\sqrt{2}
\end{align*}
hints:
Make a sketch of the region of integration and consider a change of
variables.

Change the cartesian variables $\displaystyle (x,y)$ to polar
coordinates $\displaystyle (r,\phi)$, where the boundaries of the radius
are $\displaystyle r \in [0, 2]$ and of the angle are
$\displaystyle \phi\in\left[0,\frac{\pi}{4}\right]$.
